intro: Agalinis corymbosa, commonly known as the clustered false foxglove, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Orobanchaceae family, which includes parasitic and hemiparasitic species. The plant produces showy, tubular flowers that are typically pink or purple in color, arranged in dense clusters. It thrives in sandy or loamy soils and is often found in open woodlands and disturbed areas. Agalinis corymbosa is known for its ability to form dense colonies, which can sometimes become invasive in certain regions.
